prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my mother to stay out of my finances?
I’m a 35 year old man.  i live in my brother’s home.  I work full time, but make shit money.  My brother is a veteran with PTSD, an alcoholic, and drug addict.  He lives off of disability from the VA.  He gets paid twice as much as I do to play video games and drink all day.  He got his home and mortgage through the VA.  He begged me to leave my roommates and live with him.  I pay rent.  $400/ a month.  Half his mortgage without the property taxes.  Utilities are free.  I get a small bedroom, street parking, and access to the laundry, bathroom, and kitchen.  Its not terrible, and I have been able to save a bit of money and pay off most of my college loans.  

Now, my brother had hit hard times because his vices are out of control.  He smokes $100 of weed a week.  Drinks two pints of rum a day ($11), and smokes a pack of cigarettes a day.  That is at least $870 a month.  That is what I make in two weeks.  That is only 1/4 his monthly pay.  I should point out that my brother is fully capable of working but cannot hold down a job because he shows up to work high or drunk.  

He begged me to live here.  Promised parking space in The garage and that he would build me an apartment in the basement.  

Now, he has hit hard time because of his own vices.  He went to my enabler mother for money.  She told him to raise my rent i stead of drinking less or getting a job.  

This felt like an utter betrayal to me.  I left my friend’s apartment where i was happy because i was lured with off street parking and an apartment of my own in the future to help him out.  I was doing him a favor.  Helping the family.  

Then my mother starts trying to convince him to raise my rent so he can afford his home and his booze and drugs.  

When i found out, I felt betrayed.  I told her to stay out of my finances.  I told her that if she convinces him to raise my rent, i will just get an apartment of my own (you can get them as low as $600 a month around here).  I told her that she can then keep my brother afloat and pay the rent I no longer pay.

This went over really well.  

Am I the asshole for telling my mother not to counsel my brother/landlord to raise my rent to pay for his drug habits?  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The person is a 35-year-old living with their brother, a veteran with PTSD, alcoholism, and drug addiction. The brother gets VA disability and has a mortgage through the VA. The person pays $400 a month for a room, utilities included, and has been saving and paying off loans. Now, the brother is in trouble because of his habits, and the mother suggests raising the rent to cover his expenses. The person feels betrayed and tells the mother to stay out of their finances.

So, the question is whether the author is in the wrong for telling their mother to not interfere. The user thinks the author is in the wrong, but I need to evaluate.

First, the brother's situation: he's on VA disability, which is a form of income, but he's spending a large portion on vices. The author is paying rent, which is a significant portion of the brother's income. The mother's advice seems to be pushing for the author to pay more to support the brother's lifestyle, which the author is objecting to. 

The author's reasoning is that they moved in to help the family, but now they're being asked to support the brother's vices instead of him fixing his own habits. The author is setting a boundary, which is reasonable. They're saying they won't subsidize his drug and alcohol habits. 

The mother's suggestion might be coming from a place of trying to help the brother, but it's shifting the financial burden onto the author. The author isn't in the wrong for standing up for their own finances. They've made sacrifices already by moving in, and now they're being expected to pay more when the brother isn't addressing his issues. 

The brother's responsibilities: he's an adult with his own income. The author is not obligated to support his vices. The fact that the author is working and saving while the brother isn't maintaining a job adds to the complexity. The author's response is about protecting their own financial stability, which is valid. 

The mother's role as an enabler by suggesting to raise the rent instead of addressing the brother's behaviors is problematic. The author is right to push back, as they're not responsible for the brother's choices. The fact that the author is willing to leave if the rent is raised shows they're not trying to take advantage but are standing their ground.

So, considering all that, the author isn't in the wrong. They're setting healthy boundaries and refusing to support harmful habits. The answer should be B.
